text: well I I'm not really insulted when
people call it a self-help book because
I don't know what else you would call a
book about somebody helping
themsel um although I guess a self-help
book by definition is a book that sort
of teaches like intends you know its
intention is to set out to sort of
create a path and say these are the you
know these are the steps that you have
to take um and and certainly I wouldn't
do that um because I don't know what
those steps are um but but I I
definitely you know use the book as a
way
to salvage and rescue and recreate my
own life you know by hand it was kind of
like a it was kind of like a Girl Scout
project you know like there were certain
there were materials you know like with
these materials in your own house you
too can build a you know like that's
that's kind kind of the the feeling that
I wanted it to have you know um of of a
certain kind of self- resourcefulness um
but you know I say that also with a
grain of salt because I think it's
important you know we we kind of demean
the therapeutic
um abundance that's going on in America
right now and I think we have to do that
very carefully um because some of that
stuff is really important and some of
that stuff really works and if you go to
cultures where people don't have access
to those sorts of outlets um you can see
how they might be served by them you
know um and as much as we kind of
criticize the Oprah of of of Modern Life
there's something to be argued for it as
well you know um there's a lot more
communication today in a really open way
between men and women within groups of
men and women um about what they're
feeling you know um and and what you
know what they're sad about um and that
hasn't always been the case and it's
it's not the case in every culture on
Earth um and when you go see cultures
where where people are still really
buttoned down you can see where there's
a lot of pain that's intrinsic in that
and and I myself as much as I like to
call it a sort of self-help book you
know I I I didn't set out on that
Journey until after I had been through
two years of of therapy um on the upper
west side you know um and six months to
a year I can't remember now but you know
a period of time of anti-depressants
that I was really ambivalent about but
still consider a bridge a sort of
necessary Bridge to get me through the
last awful months of my divorce um I
probably could have done it without it
but it made it a lot less anguish you
know um anguishing for me so um you know
but that too was I guess even so seeking
out help from a professional um you know
I took look I took whatever was
available you know um
religion Psychotherapy friendship
companionship exercise drinking eight
glasses of water a day look whatever was
on hand I was using because I was in a
lot of trouble um and you know the last
step of it was going off on this journey
but if I I certainly wouldn't have been
physically or mentally able to do that
even a year before um because I was in
such a bad place so I would caution
people against sort of Leaping off a
cliff um in some sort of grandiose
gesture of self- reclamation if they're
not you know if they're not actually
somewhat mentally or psychologically
stable enough to handle it
